title: brexit last ditch talks mired
story: NewsBrexit: Last-ditch talks mired in deadlock as No admit its proving dficultThings look no closer to being solved despite just  days remaining before were meant to leave the EUShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorGavin Cordon:,  MAR NewsTheresa May looked no closer to a breakthrough today "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit talks appear mired in deadlock with just  days to go after the UK and EU admitted things are proving dficult.Theresa May looked no closer to a breakthrough today despite holding a trio of crucial House of Commons votes next week.MPs will vote by next Tuesday on whether to accept her Brexit deal, whatever form its in and whether she gets any revisions.If it fails, they will vote by Wednesday on whether to accept No Deal Brexit . That could then trigger a vote to delay Brexit on Thursday.Yet for all the talk of Mrs May unveiling changes on Monday, the signs from Brussels and London today were bleak.A press conference was killed off after y talks last night between the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier, Attorney General Geoffrey Cox and Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay.  The European Commission said there was still no solution to the Irish backstop, a clause in the -page deal that could trap the UK under EU customs rules from . And today, Downing Street said there had been a robust exchange of views as Mr Cox tried to persuade the EU side to accept legally-binding changes. The Prime Minister has said she wants the changes to the backstop to ensure the UK is not tied to EU rules indefinitely. She was originally requesting either a time limit, exit clause or some other alternative arrangements. However, Mr Barnier told the weekly meeting of the College of Commissioners in Brussels that the negotiations were proving dficult and a way forward had not been found.   The commissions chief spokesman Margaritis Schinas told reporters: Michel Barnier was present and informed the commissioners that while the talks take place in a constructive atmosphere, discussions have been dficult. No solution has been identied at this point that is consistent with the Withdrawal Agreement, including the protocol on Ireland Northern Ireland which, as you all know, will not be reopened. Mrs Mays official spokesman told reporters at Westminster: My understanding is that the talks were dficult and there was a robust exchange of views. However, talks are ongoing. The EU continues to say that it wants this to be resolved and that it wants the UK to leave with a deal. Parliament has been clear that for this to happen, we require legally-binding changes which mean that the UK cant be trapped in the backstop indefinitely. That is what we will continue to pursue.   Arriving back in London on Wednesday, Mr Cox told the BBC: This is a moment where we are in the midst of the very heart of discussions. We have made very reasonable, very coherent, very detailed proposals. We are resuming talks soon and we shall have to see where they go. But we are having a good dialogue and a good exchange of views. Askedhe was confident of getting a solution, Mr Cox said: We will have to see. We are certainly constructively engaging at the moment. Meanwhile, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox has refused to rule out backing a no-dealBrexit the Withdrawal Agreement is voted down by MPs next week. Dr Fox, who campaigned for Leave in the  referendum, told the Commons International Trade Committee that no-deal was hugely sub-optimal, compared to getting a deal. The Brexit deal agreed by Theresa May and the EU covers two areas: the Withdrawal Agreement, covering the UKs exit from the EU, and the Political Declaration on a Future Framework, which sets out the relationship with the EU after Britain leaves. Key details on the Brexit deal include: . The Withdrawal AgreementThe transition period can be extended until  - after the next election Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK A backstop could extend EU customs rules UK-wide - and wed need Brussels permission to quit European courts will still have a big hold on the UK. The Future FrameworkComprehensive arrangements that will create a free trade area - not exactly the frictionless trade hoped for Possible EU access to British fishing waters We would remain tied to European courts Wed respect human rights laws Visas needed for long term trips to the EU It has built in vagueness - kicking the can down the road for further negotiationsRead about the deal in more depth here.  Asked whether the Government would back no-deal in the vote scheduled for the following daythe agreement fails, he said: Potentially all things are possible. With the scheduled date ofBrexitjust  days away on March , Environment Secretary Michael Gove warned that MPs may be asked to give up their Easter break - due to begin on April  - to deal with the avalanche of legislation which needs to be passed. He told a parliamentary committee: The Chief Whip has reminded Conservative MPs that there may not be an Easter recess. With ToryBrexiteers still refusing to commit to voting for the agreement, ministers have acknowledged they may need the support of opposition MPsthe deal is to get through Parliament on Tuesday.However, the latest attempt to win over wavering Labour MPs with new measures to protect workers rights outside the EU has met with a dismissive response from trade unions.Under the proposals, MPs will be allowed to vote on whether to take new EU workplace rules, rather than them being automatically written into UK law. Trades Union Congress general secretary Frances OGrady said the announcement was blatant window dressing that left protections under threat. Working people need a cast-iron, legal guarantee that rights like these will be safe afterBrexit, and that guarantee should be written into the deal, she said.Jeremy Corbyn is to meet with Conservative MPs backing a Norway-style relationship with the EU afterBrexit, Labour has said.A party spokesman said Mr Corbyn would be seeing former ministers Sir Oliver Letwin and Nick Boles as part of a group of Labour and Tory MPs who support the so-called Common Market . model of a close economic relationship. The spokesman said the meeting was to discuss how to achieve a deal that would be good for jobs and could bring Leave and Remain voters together.

title: jeremy corbyn working tory backbenchers
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn working with Tory backbenchers to reach soft Brexit dealEXCLUSIVE: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has held in-depth talks with cross-party MPS who are backing a Norway-plus style BrexitShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAR NewsJeremy Corbyn is working with Tory backbenchers to try and reach a soft Brexit deal "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyn is working with Tory backbenchers to try to reach a ‘soft’ Brexit deal that can get the support of Parliament. The Labour leader held in-depth talks with a cross-party group of MPs who are backing a Norway-plus style Brexit.Afterwards, he said felt “more certain” and “more determined” than ever that a sensible compromise could be struck. Mr Corbyn hopes to secure a close economic relationship with the EU after Brexit that would keep both Leave and Remain voters happy. And he wants to move beyond Brexit to concentrate on crucial domestic issues that are currently being neglected.  But his interest in the Norway Plus proposals will increase Government fears that MPs could force a ‘softer’ deal, including a customs union, in the event they reject Theresa May ’s deal for a second time next week.Writing for the Mirror, Mr Corbyn said: “I left both meetings more certain than ever that we can find a way to work across Parliament to force the Government to back a sensible Brexit plan that protects jobs and more determined to achieve it. “I will continue to reach out to get a decent Brexit deal so our country can spend more time talking about our children’s future than a customs union.”It comes after Tory chief whip Julian Smith warned the cabinet that Parliament could take control of the timetablethe PM is again defeated. MPs are then likely to vote to take a No Deal Brexit off the table and to delay Brexit.Labour sources suggested the party could then, in theory, back a cross-party amendment for a series of ‘indicative’ votes.   This could then pave the way for a vote guaranteeing the future political relationship, including a customs union. A senior Labour source said: “We’re genuinely trying to find a way through which we know involves working wth others in Parliament. “We’re not necessarily going to mind in future whose name is on an amendmentthe outcome is what brings the country together.” The cross-party group - Tories Nick Boles and Oliver Letwin and Labour’s Lucy Powell and Stephen Kinnock- believe their ‘Common Market’ . plan for the UK’s future relationship with the EU could get through Parliament. It almost mirrors Labour’s own call for a close economic relationship with the EU, including a permanent customs union, which was rejected by MPs last month. Both plans would see common external tarfs, follow common rules and mean the UK would negotiate trade deals as part of the EU bloc. The Norway Plus option would see the UK seek a close relationship with the EU, but stop short of full membership. This ‘soft Brexit’ plan, would involve Britain joining the European Economic Areaand the European Free Trade Associationalongside Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein. It would mean Britain regains sovereignty over food and fisheries, and would mean we are no longer beholden to EU courts. Anda customs agreement can be reached, it would give the most simple solution to the Irish border question - the biggest stumbling block in reaching a deal. It would keep Britain in the single market - which would mean we would still have to accept free movement of people. And we would still have to make a reduced contribution to the EU budget. But as a member of EFTA we would be allowed to impose an emergency brake on immigration should it be shown to be causing social or economic problems.  However, the cross-party group’s Norway Plus plan would only be temporary, until frictionless trade could be resolved by other means. This means that it could potentially get the support of enough Tory MPs to get through Parliament. Manchester Central MP Ms Powell said: “We all left the meeting feeling this was a very genuine and positive endeavour to seek cross-party consensus to break the Brexit deadlock. Tory MP for Grantham Mr Boles added: “If the PM’s deal is defeated next weekParliament will need to find a cross-party compromise. It is very welcome that the Leader of the Opposition is engaging so seriously with the Common Market . plan.” It came as Downing Street admitted that talks between the UK and EU to try to get concessions to win over Tory Brexiteers had been “dficult”, after Attorney General Geoffrey Cox ed from Brussels empty handed.  The House of Lords last night dealt another blow to the PM by demanding that Britain join a customs union on the day it leaves the EU. The amendment, supported by Labour, Lib Dems and crossbench peers, will force the PM to schedule another vote in the Commonsshe wants to maintain her current policy of leaving the customs union when we leave the EU. It is also another sign of Labour moving to put in place arrangements for a softer Brexit deal.

title: you renew your passport friday
story: NewsYou may have to renew your passport by this Friday - or be barred from EuropeTravellers could fall foul of rules for entering countries in the Schengen zone such as France, Spain and ItalyShareCommentsByOliver Milne:,  MAR NewsThe warning comes from consumer rights experts Which  "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe deadline to renew your passportyou are planning to travel in Europe could be as soon as this Friday - a consumer rights group has claimed.The millions of UK travellers planning to travel on the continent could be barred from entering several European countries in the event of a no-deal Brexit unless they renew their passports by Friday, according to Which Holiday makers and business travellers risk falling foul of rules for entering countries in the Schengen zone such as France, Spain and Italy.   Visitors usually need at least six months left on their passport from the date they arrive. Until recently, UK citizens who renewed their passport before it expired could have up to nine months of the remaining validity added to their new travel document. The Government has warned that this time carried over will not count towards the six-month requirement after a no-deal Brexit, meaning people with up to  months left on their passport could be denied entry to many popular destinations on the continent. Figures obtained by Which  show that around . million current British passports will not comply with the validity rules. The consumer group noted that Friday will be three weeks before the UK is due to withdraw from the EU, which is the time it takes for passports to arrive after a standard renewal application.   Rory Boland, editor of Which  Travel magazine, said: Millions of people could find their holiday plans disrupted or, worse yet, find themselves stranded at the departure gate and prevented from travelling altogetherthey fail to renew their passport before the cut-off date. Anyone who thinks they might be affected should look to renew their passport today oryou already have travel plans in the near future, consider using the fast-track passport renewal service.

title: pregnant mum expecting long lost
story: NewsPregnant mum expecting long-lost brothers child died after painkiller overdoseAnnmarie Thomas was addicted to over-the-counter painkillers after the death of her grandparentsShareByAnna LewisTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsAnnmarie Thomas was rushed to Princess of Wales Hospital after falling sick on September  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pregnant mother who was expecting a child with her long-lost brother died of rapid onset liver failure after unintentionally overdosing on painkillers. Annmarie Thomas, , died in hospital on September , just days after being confronted about her addiction to painkillers. An inquest into her death revealed that she became isolated after witnessing the death of her grandmother in  and her grandfather in . She started to buy over-the-counter painkillers to sooth stomach pain, an inquest heard.  Mrs Thomas was taken to Princess of Wales Hospital on September  last year after complaining of vomiting and being unable to sleep, Wales Online reports.She was placed on a le-support blood dialysis machine, meaning her unstable condition and pregnancy made her an unsuitable candidate for an emergency liver tranplant. In a statement summarised in court, former husband Gareth Thomas said: [Her grandmothers death] had a massive impact on Annmaries mental and physical health. She became increasingly isolated and started complaining of pain and other ailments. It was at this time that Annmarie started to take over-the-counter medication.   He also said Mrs Thomas found out she had a long-lost brother Ryan Murphy. He said she was getting better after having met him face-to-face in  for the first time. She was finding comfort in it and was making up for time they had missed, Mr Thomas added. The inquest heard Mr Thomas and his we had married in  and ended their -year marriage on good terms. In February , Mrs Thomas formed a relationship with Mr Murphy. During the inquest, Mr Murphy said he found Mrs Thomas, who was -weeks pregnant, unwell after ing to their home in North Cornelly on September . She was rushed to the Princess of Wales Hospital and taken to an obstetrics and gynaecology ward before being put on a le-support machine in intensive care. In a statement read in court Mr Murphy described himself as devastated by his partners death. He said: We had a very loving and happy relationship together. We had massive plans for the future regarding our home le and unborn child. She never failed to tell me how much she loved me. She was even planning to change her last name to be a family together.   Asked about Mrs Thomas addiction to painkillers he said: We didnt meet each other until December []. I didnt know I had Annmarie as a relative until she contacted my mother about six years before that. I didnt know about the addiction. It became more clear when I moved into the house with her. I didnt know about the quantities – it was just something that Annmarie always did. I never questioned how much she took. We did experience one or two confrontations about it – the most recent one was about two or three days before she died. Giving evidence, intensive care doctor Joseph Riddell said he was alerted to Mrs Thomass condition after finding a shocked result from her blood test. Dr Riddell said: Acid levels in the blood are normally .[pH]. Annmaries level of acid was very low which was very dangerous. It was .. When the blood goes below seven its a sign that the blood is very acidic and the patient is unwell. When it drops below seven its a sign that the patient is highly likely to die. She was very agitated and very distressed. She was hyperventilating which is the bodys response to having acidic blood. Dr Ridell said Mrs Thomas went on to suffer two cardiac arrests, both before and after being fitted onto the dialysis machine, but was revived both times. After contacting Kings College Hospital in London, the hospital were told Mrs Thomas was unsuitable for super-urgent liver transplant due to her unstable condition and pregnancy.Dr Riddell said: She received a cocktail of very potent cardiac support drugs. Despite that her circulation continued to deteriorate as her blood pressure continued to drop.She died on maximum le support. Returning a conclusion of non-illicit drug-related death, assistant coroner Nadim Bashir said Mrs Thomas had died as a result of rapid onset liver failure caused by unintentional paracetamol overdose.

title: mans double life exposed two
story: NewsMans double le was exposed when TWO girlfriends met over his hospital bed - then they healed each others heartsKathleen Maloney, , was devastated after discovering her partner of five years had spent the last  years with Susan - before both women decided to help each other through their painShareCommentsByKathleen Maloney:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsKathleenand Susanhelped one another through the pain and heartache "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBubbles. Susan and I laughed until our sides hurt at the nickname we had both been given. Id once thought of it as affectionate and sweetly romantic - but now the moniker which tied me to this wonderful woman stood for nothing but lies. Well were good women - and now he has lost both of us, we told one another. We were duped by Anthony. I had made le-changing decisions for this man in the name of a very misplaced love. But, through our pain, loss and deep betrayal, Susan and I found one another.   I met Anthony in , and was smitten from the first dinner date when he took me to a fancy restaurant on the ocean front. He was ft, extremely handsome and, even better - a true gentleman. Id got lucky with this one. He opened every door, paid for every date and after that first dinner, he gently placed his coat over my shoulders as we walked along the sea-front. I was during those heady, wonderful first few weeks and months of our relationship that I fell for him. It was surreal - like something out of a movie. It felt wonderful to feel those butterflies again. He made me feel beautul, showering me with affection. But something didnt feel entirely right from the beginning. He would disappear for weeks at a time without warning, and when I suggested he didnt feel as strongly about me, he told me his feelings actually ran so deep for me, it frightened him. Ive never met a good woman like you before, he would tell me. The periods away continued, but after two years of dating, we grew incredibly close and began talking about our future together. We planned our future in the sunshine, we laughed together, we held hands while eating at restaurants - we were in love.   A year passed by and despite our undeniable chemistry, I still felt something wasnt right and Anthony wasnt fully letting me into his le. I asked him about why I hadnt met any of his children, so he invited his son to join us for dinner - although he was always too busy. Never dreaming this man could go on to hurt me so badly, I went on to honour his request to join his church as a way of proving my commitment. My commitment  It really all seems laughable now. But I did just that, and joined in the hope of one day becoming his we. Though I still had some unease about our relationship, I felt more confident because he asked me to be a part of something I knew was incredibly meaningful to him. Then came the call that would change everything, shattering this so-called love story to pieces. Wed been together for five years, and Anthony had gone into hospital for minor surgery. The operation went well, he told me assuredly in the unexpected phone call. I thought your surgery was scheduled for tomorrow I said, surprised and confused how he hadnt filled me in. Anthony told me doctors had managed to move it forward a day, adding that he was in quarantine for a few more days so it wouldnt be worth visiting. But this was the man I loved, laying in hospital, alone and in pain.   I did what any caring person would and hopped in the car, drove the two hours to his hospital to pay him a surprise visit. And what a surprise it turned out to be - for us all. After checking in and receiving my visitors pass, I took the lt to the sixth floor and I made my way to Anthonys room. A nurse was working on him, so I said hello to him from across the room. Something was obviously not right - Anthony meekly replied hello, but seemed quiet and cold towards me. He had never acted like this around me before and this was not the man I knew. I recognised Anthonys son sat at his bedside from pictures, but couldnt place the woman he was chatting to. She smiled warmly at me and even got up to give me her seat before pulling a spare chair over and sitting down again. We made small talk about the beautul view of Manhattan from Anthonys hospital window. She was easy to talk to and I instantly liked her. We even shared a few laughs before I started the introductions. Im Kathy, by the way. Im Susan, she replied, holding out her hand with a warm smile. In the moments that followed, I had no idea Id grow to love that welcoming, kind smile - a hint at the beautul person she is. Susan - the name rattled around my head. I thought back to a year earlier when Anthony had mentioned his ex-girlfriends name was Susan.   He assured me then that their relationship was long over, telling me I have no idea what happened to her. I didnt want to act too hastily, but instead tried making small talk with Anthony - who by this point refused to engage with me and seemed really tense. I had to get to the bottom of this. “So, how long have you known Anthony  I asked Susan. For eighteen years., she replied frankly. My stomach dropped. I askedwe could talk in the corridor, hearing Anthony mumble, Oh brother, here we go. Here comes the pow-wow, as we left. Alone in the hallway, we told each other everything. I told Susan I had been in a relationship with Anthony for the past five years. I told her how he often discussed our future together and how he had suggested we move somewhere warm like South Carolina. Susans face grew more and more distraught as I continued to tell her about my relationship with him. Then came my turn. Susan took a deep breath before telling me she had been in a committed relationship with Anthony for eighteen years and had even gone shopping for engagement rings before his surgery. I couldnt believe what I was hearing. My le as Id come to know it had ended in this cold hospital hallway.   Then my heart broke all over again - this time, for Susan. Susan asked meAntony ever criticised me, put me down, critiqued my clothes, make-up and body shape. I was stunned, but after promising her Id be % honest, I told Susan that Anthony had made me feel beautul. And he did. He had always treated me with respect and kindness. He was gentle, loving and soft-spoken with me. Susan outlined a very dferent side to him I had never known. I asked Susan, How did we not run into each other at Anthonys home  Didnt you see the bar of Irish Spring soap I left in his shower  She rolled her eyes, I used it, she replied. The more we talked, the more we learned about the two lives Anthony had been living and how he kept us apart. Susan was a good-looking woman who seemed smart and caring, so I asked her why she hadnt left. She didnt respond, but stared blankly at the floor of the hallway. I assured her my relationship with Anthony would end, before walking back into his room to collect my things. I told Anthony everything, but he had nothing to say. He knew it was over.   As I was about to leave, something incredible happened. Anthonys son stopped me, apologised for his fathers behavior and askedhe could hug me. I drove home in a daze, thinking of Susan, wondering why she had stayed with him all these years. She deserved so much better -we both did. I was broken hearted and I felt physically sick for days after that afternoon in the hospital. Discovering Anthony was a player and a liar hit me hard. How could I have been so gullible  Did he think we would never find out what he was doing  My mind was racing with so many questions. Two months after our chance meeting in the hospital, Susan looked up my number and reached out to me. She told me that she had some more questions for me and I answered all of them the best that I could. Susan said she had hoped to marry Anthony one day, but he always had a reason why he wouldnt go through with the wedding - and it was usually a cruel one. Our regular chats on the phone soon turned to topics outside of our ex. We lted each other up and the more we learned about each other, the more we liked.

title: food banks poverty england help
story: AdvertorialHow hard-up families are saving % on their supermarket shopping billsNew initiative also helps people with their finances with free budget adviceShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR AdvertorialMembers are able to take advantage of the scheme for up to six months while they find their feet "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pioneering community cafe is transforming lives by offering discounted shopping and hot meals, employment help and financial advice. Cafe Number  is a membership-based, not-for-profit citizens supermarket and cafe. The outlet sells surplus food donated from supermarkets at a discount, with prices at least two-thirds lower than a normal shop. It also serves wholesome, healthy and affordable meals where a family of four can dine for under pound. And after visitors have completed their shopping, they can sit with a coffee and speak to specialist advisors who will help get them back into work, or work with them to consolidate their debt into a manageable payment. The team at the cafe, which is based in Birkenhead, Merseyside, also offer interview techniques, help with improving CVs and even secure them work. “The idea is that we help people help themselves. They stay with us until we sort them out and when they are flourishing, they can move on,” said project coordinator Andrew Forsey.  “We also want to enable people on low incomes to access affordable food in a dignied and welcoming environment. Andrew works with Birkenhead’s independent MP Frank Field, and the cafe is run in partnership with Feeding Birkenhead, a coalition of local community groups. “A driving force is to offer an intervention to people. For someone who is struggling from week to week, it can sometimes just take one event like a broken fridge or unexpected large bill to find yourself in crisis. So shopping with us for a while will help keep them ticking over while we can advise over how best to get a grip of underlying debt problems.” Members are able to take advantage of the scheme for up to six months while they find their feet. “We are working with around  iniduals and their families,” said Andrew. “These are people that were mostly referred by a local housing association but in future we are working with people who come to us from job center.” In the future the centre hopes to help in other areas, like cookery classes. “We have had members tell us, that they buy the food but could do with help with ideas of how to make meals, so that is something we will look to launch soon too.” Staff and volunteers at Number  have also been specically chosen from the community. Those who have been out of work for a while or who need a confidence boost have been employed. Andrew added: “An unexpected boost has been the benefit to people’s mental health, those who have felt isolated and have come here for a shop, a meal, a coffee, have reported feeling uplted.”For more Stories of Local Pride, click here

story: NewsHuntsmen clash with saboteurs as  hounds chase fox through graveyardExperts say the fox was either pregnant, of had recently given birth, before it was chased down by the pack of dogs in SomersetShareCommentsByAlex ShipmanKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video horrying-moment--hours-chase-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than  dogs were filmed chasing a fox though a graveyard as huntsmen clashed with saboteurs. The horric footage shows the vixen, believed to be heavily pregnant or to have very recently given birth, running into bushes. She races away across a field before a man on horseback wearing hunting attire sounds a horn from a neighbouring field, in Charlton Horethorne, Somerset. Another hunter on a white horse is then challenged by an animal welfare campaigner as a hound closes in on its prey. The campaigner who filmed the clip tells him: You pull him off! You pull him off that fox right now!   The hunter replies: Im doing it - get out the way. The five-minute video, captured on Saturday, February , was released by animal welfare campaigners Hounds Off and Somerset Wildle Crime. The village of Charlton Horethorne is the home of the Blackmore and Sparkford Vale Hunt which meets at least three times a week. Somerset Wildle Crime tracks the hunts to protect foxes and raise awareness of the practice.   Spokesman Bobbie Armstrong, , said: When the fox crossed in front of us we told a red-coated hunter to call hounds off. At this point, they were right on her and it looked grim. It was all a bit tense for a while. During hunts, we will find vantage points and plot the direction they will travel so we can get ahead of the hounds. We are capturing compelling video evidence to support our case against this cruel and inhumane practice. It was the Blackmore and Sparkford Vale hunt who meet at least three times a week.   People dont realise that hunting still goes on and it happens all through the week. In Somerset, you could witness a hunt every day. Only the presence of so many cameras brings the hunt to their senses and they have to stop the hounds after the second circuit for fear of what the cameras have captured. Penny Little, founder of the Little Foxes charity, reviewed the footage and said: I am confident this fox is a vixen that has recently given birth to cubs as her teats are visible and show clear evidence of lactation.

title: i live caravan government helps
story: NewsI live in a caravan while government helps itself to £bn of our pension cashKen Sullivan and his we Eira pocket only £ per week from his miners pension instead of £ShareCommentsByRobin Eveleigh:,  MAR NewsKen Sullivan "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFormer miner Ken Sullivan should be making the most of his shyretirement now after  years down the pit and triple heart shybypass surgery seven years ago. But he and we Eira cannot afford nights out or holidays and budget everything down to the last penny. Things would be easierthey had the other half of Ken’s miner’s pension, pocketing pound a week instead of pound. But the Government has that – part of the poundbillion that has been raided from miners’ pension pots since .  Ken, , of Tredegar, Gwent, has heard thousands of heartbreaking stories over the past three years as he visited every village and town in the impoverished former pit communities of South Wales, gathering signatures for a petition against the “great pension deception”. And yesterday, he joined colleagues from Yorkshire, the North East, Kent and Nottinghamshire to deliver the ,-name document to Downing Street, demanding back the cash that so many have been “robbed” of. Ken, who worked at Oakdale Colliery, said: “We’ve had tremendous support but it’s been shocking to discover even miners themselves are oblivious to the depths of this betrayal. “Their communities have been destroyed and they’ve been left to scrape by on a pittance while the Government uses their pension billions as a slush fund to dip into at will. “Gathering signatures, I spoke to one widow who gets pound. a week. Her husband spent a letime underground and died at . The Government has had more than its fair share. It’s time to stop.”   The scandal dates to , when British Coal was privatised. The Government vowed to back two funds – the Miners’ Pension Scheme and the British Coal Staff Superannuation Scheme – infor a - split on any surplus earned. It was estimated the funds would earn the Treasury poundbillion over the next  years with members sharing the same sum. But Energy Minister Claire Perry confessed the Government has had pound.billion from the MPS alone since  and the Tories have taken poundmillion since  – poundmillion in  alone. They plan to take another poundmillion over the next three years. Meanwhile, former miners get an average of pound a week.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn – who signed the petition – said: “It is scandalous.“There must be a renegotiation and the Government must correct this injustice.”  In the week marking  years since the end of the - strike, the sense of injustice is still strong. Paul Stevey was an electrician at Manchester’s Agecroft Colliery and is now living in a caravan on a pension of just pound a week. The -year-old, of Allonby, Cumbria, said: “I sold my home six years ago and the caravan was meant to be a stop-gap while I found something smaller. But the cost of living ate into my savings and now I can’t afford to buy a home. I get another pound a week from my late we’s pension but it’s all soon gone once I’ve paid site fees and utilities, I barely have enough to live on.“Even so, that bit of income means I haven’t been able to get Universal Credit or access free training schemes.” Emlyn Davies moved in with daughter Maggie in Mountain Ash, South Wales, six years ago after losing we Gwynneth.The -year-old, in remission from prostate cancer, cut coal by hand from . He was made redundant during the closure of Penrhiwceiber Colliery in  and gets pound a week. Emlyn says: “We ended up selling our house. Gwynneth and I moved into a council house and later our savings dwindled as I nursed her. I took her death badly and moved in with Maggie in . “I shouldn’t be in this position. There’s no way I could afford to live alone. The Government kidnapped our money.”  His friend Harry Parfitt, also at Penrhiwceiber, is wheelchair-bound with a spine condition he says was caused by pit work. He paid into the pot from  yet gets just pound a week. Harry, , has spent years helping to gather signatures and says: “I’m doing this for everyone suffering because the Government robbed our money. The miners never agreed to this - split, the unions didn’t agree – what has happened is criminal.” MPs Jonathan Edwards and Liz Saville Roberts of Plaid Cymru turned out for the petition hand-over at pm. Mick Newton, of the UK Mineworkers’ Pension Association, said efforts compiling it were “testament to the strength of feeling on this”. Minister Claire Perry last year asked the Department for Business to liaise with pension trustees and “explore options” for a review. She said this week: “I’ve received some interesting proposals from the trustees we are currently considering.” The MPS said talks were confidential, adding: “When there is any news, we will communicate with the scheme’s members.”

title: inside dark history house visited
story: NewsInside dark history of house on street Prince William and Kate Middleton visitedDavid Minto, then , carried out the sexual assault and murder of Sasha Marsden, , near the Grafton House Hotel in Blackpool which forms part of a renovation project visited by the Duke and Duchess of CambridgeShareCommentsByRussell MyersLaura Forsyth:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during a visit to Kirby Road in Blackpool "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince William and Kate Middleton were shown around a refurbishment project during their Blackpool trip - and one of the homes on the street they visited has a rather sinister history. The royal couple visited Kirby Road, where the Blackpool Housing Company has bought several dilapidated properties and is transforming them to rent as safe, family homes. But the history of one of the mould-ridden houses in the street proved to be quite unnerving as it was the scene of a murder in . One of the properties on the road the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visited used to be known as the Grafton House Hotel, where David Minto, then , lured -year-old Sasha Marsden to her death on the  promise of a job. It was here that he stabbed her  times in an attack described in court as sexually motivated.  Minto, who was jailed for le, dumped Sashas body, wrapped in a bin liner and carpet underlay, in an alleyway near the hotel. Now, that side of the road has been fully renovated while the opposite side remains dilapidated, ready to be targeted in the next phase. The Duke and Duchess first took a tour of a run-down house, asking Lee Burrell from the housing company how they identied the properties in need of urgent renovation. “Are they quite well hidden ” William asked. They then crossed the street, pausing to say hello to four small children, to be welcomed into a new house now lived in by Christina Jackson, .  Miss Jones, who lost pound, of her deposit after she left her old rented property due to large cracks in the wall and peeling paint, said she had felt much more settled since moving to a new home in January. “When did you move in ” the Duchess asked. “Thank you for having us.” The Duke, spotting members of the media, joked: “I hope they all wiped their feet.” Sitting in the living room, Miss Jackson described how she had been left out of pocket and was still catching up with payments while living on benefits for her mental health issues.  “This was a private landlord was it ” asked the Duke, who was told she could not get her money back. “You never had any contact or feedback  No response  No help  “It must have been very frustrating and very depressing for you to deal with that.” The Duchess asked whether the human interaction with her new landlords, where she can speak to office staff on the phone, had been helpful. “It seems really nice here,” said William. “Do you feel more settled ” The Duchess was interested in the decor, wondering: “Can you make changes and choices ”  The couple were particularly keen to hear about the support residents received for mental health issues, with Kate asking: “Do you find it hard to reach out ” Miss Jackson said afterwards: “They said the house is absolutely lovely. They’re so down to earth, they really got it. They seem to know everything that was going on and were very understanding.” Lee Burrell, development director at Blackpool Housing Company, said the couple were “incredibly interested” in the project, and had expressed their concern that people might move back into housing of such poor standard. “They seemed quite shocked,” he said. “There was an element of surprise that properties could be in that position.” Alan Cavill, Director of regeneration at Blackpool Council, said: “I think they were very concerned to know what could be done. “The Duchess was clearly unhappy about the fact that children had been living there - it’s not a place she would want to see any child.”

title: madeleine mccann netflix documentary slammed
story: NewsMadeleine McCann Netflix documentary slammed by Kate and GerryKate and Gerry McCann have refused to participate in Netflix documentary "The Disappearance of Madeleine McCann" which is expected to air later this monthShareByNeil Murphy:,  MAR NewsKate and Gerry McCann pose with an artists impression of how their daughter might look now at the age of nine "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMadeleine McCanns parents have slammed a controversial new Netflix documentary about the disappearance of their daughter. Kate and Gerry McCann have refused to participate in the eight-part-crime series The Disappearance of Madeleine McCann, saying it could hinder an ongoing police investigation. According to reports, the streaming giant is expected to air the programme about the three-year-olds disappearance later this month.Madeleine was three when she was last seen while on holiday with her parents Gerry and Kate in Praia da Luz, Portugal, in May . In a statement, her parents said: We are aware that Netflix are planning to screen a documentary in March  about Madeleines disappearance.  The production company told us that they were making the documentary and asked us to participate. We did not see - and still do not see - how this programme will help the search for Madeleine and, particularly given there is an active police investigation, it could potentially hinder it. Consequently, our views and preferences are not reflected in the programme.   We will not be making any further statements or giving interviews regarding this programme. Mr and Mrs McCann have always pledged to never give up the search for their daughter. Scotland Yard launched its own investigation, Operation Grange, into her disappearance in , after a Portuguese inquiry failed to make any headway.  In November last year, a further pound, was granted to the investigation to allow it to continue until March . Force bosses have been applying for funding from the Home Office every six months to continue the inquiry, which has cost about pound. million so far.

story: NewsMeghan Markle makes surprise appearance as cheeky Prince Harry drags her on stagePrince Harry was speaking at an event for WE when he brought pregnant Meghan Markle out onto the stage to huge cheers and screams from the audienceShareCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video harry-brings-meghan-stage-front-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Meghan Markle delighted guests at a very special event at Wembley when she made a surprise appearance at stage thanks to a very cheeky Prince Harry .The dad-to-be was speaking at WE Day UK, a scheme which helps young people be a part of positive social change around the world, when he decided Meghan should get involved. To be happy is to be mindful, mindful of your feelings, mindful of your surroundings, and mindful of the . billion other humans that inhabit this planet. Every forest, every river, every ocean, every coastline, everyinsect, everywild animal.Every blade of grass, every ray of sun and every rain drop is crucial to our survival. Be braver Be stronger Be kind to each other Be kind to yourselves Have less screen time, and more face to face time Exceed expectations Eliminate plastics Conserve water Protect wildle and their unique habitat Keep empathy alive Ask your friends how they are doing and listen to the answer Be honest Take risks Change your thoughts and change the world Dare to be thegreatest generation of all time I am with you, we are with you!

title: mum spent almost 50 minutes
story: NewsMum spent almost  minutes on phone before finding baby drowned in bathSarah Elizabeth Morris, from Bagilit in Flintshire left daughter Rosie and her twin brother in the bath unattended while she talked to her partner, jurors heardShareByLydia Morris:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSarah Morris was on the phone to her partner while her twin children were in the bath unattended, jurors heard "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA one-year-old baby drowned when she was left unattended in a bath while her mum was on the phone, a court heard. Sarah Elizabeth Morris was talking to her partner when daughter Rosie,  months, drowned. Morris, , has been charged with manslaughter and child cruelty, which she denies, North Wales Live reports. Rosie was left in the bath for prolonged periods, Mold Crown Court in Wales was told on the first day of Morris trial. The court heard that the mum - who has been unable to provide a clear account of what happened - was on the phone to her then partner Sarah Swindles for almost  minutes while her children were in the bath. Oliver Saxby, prosecuting, told jurors that Morris, who had been popping her head around the door on occasion, had gone to check on the twins after Ms Swindles advised her to do so.  But when she did, she discovered Rosie had downed. Morris, from Bagilit in Flintshire, Wales, called her friend Jemma Egerton, who she had known for about a month, to tell her that Rosie wasnt breathing and that she didnt know what had happened to her, the court heard. After almost  minutes on the phone, Ms Egerton ended the call by advising Morris to dial . Instead, Morris rushed into the street holding Rosie upside down and shouting for help, leaving her son in the bath. Her neighbour Christine Murphy called for help before taking them both back inside. There were prolonged periods when she was not checking on them and had forgotten about them and the danger they were in, said Mr Saxby.  Neither baby had any child support with them in the bathroom to stabilise or prevent them from falling over. They were left in an extremely vulnerable position. As a result of her failure to supervise the twins as they sat unsupported, one of them drowned. In a police interview following the incident, Morris said that, before she found her daughter, she was in the kitchen doing the washing and heating the towels so they they were warm when they got out of the bath. She told officers that it was after she had been for a cigarette in her bedroom that she thought she heard the plug being pulled in the bath. Morris said she went to look and that was when she found Rosie lying on her back in the bath. She said she performed CPR on her daughter before running out into the street for help. The court heard she told doctors at the hospital where Rosie was taken that she had only left the children for five minutes to get some towels when she found her daughter lying in the bath on her back. The trial continues.

story: AdvertorialFears over new technologies which are improving faster than human skills areYorkshire Banks Group Business Banking Director gives his verdict on the biggest technology questions for small businesses in ShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Advertorial"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTechnology is vital for all businesses up and down the country. So to help, Yorkshire Bank’s Group Business Banking Director, Gavin Opperman, is here to answer your questions... Q How can small businesses reduce costs associated with new technology  A Every small business needs technology to support them to make their business more efficient. Technology is moving faster than human skills are, which is why it is necessary for small businesses to weigh up exactly what piece of technology they want to own, its longevity and whether its development can be outsourced. Q Many small businesses are hindered by time and internal resources – how can they still embrace new technology  A The biggest challenge Yorkshire Bank has identied with small businesses is the skills shortage, which puts pressure on internal resources. A lot of universities are developing skills in technology, but it’s how small businesses can retain the talent within that. The aim would be to keep the intellectual property within  the region, so small businesses can embrace new technology without added time or training.Find out more about a business bank that works for you at YBonline business

title: smokers who give up cigarettes
story: NewsSmokers who give up cigarettes and take up vaping instead save £ per yearA new survey has found the typical smoker has been smoking for  years and smokes  cigarettes a dayShareCommentsByRob Knight:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsA quarter of smokers would NOT try vaping as they believe theyre as bad for you as cigarettes [file image] "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA quarter of smokers would NOT try vaping – with many believing it is just as bad for you as cigarettes, a study found. Researchers found tobacco users are ‘suspicious’ of e-cigarettes and have no desire to give vapes a go - despite health professionals urging them to do so. It also emerged two thirds have attempted to kick the habit at one time or another – four times on average – but to date they haven’t managed to stop for good. Stress, peer pressure and a lack of support were identied as the biggest reasons why they haven’t been successful. Commissioned by Yorkshire Cancer Research, the survey of  smokers and , ex-smokers found the typical smoker has been puffing away for  years and gets through  cigarettes a day.   Chief executive Dr Kathryn Scott said: “Vaping is a great tool to help people quit – and it’s  per cent less harmful than cigarettes. “But everyone is dferent, so the best way to help you give up is to get support from a local stop smoking service. “These services understand people smoke for a whole host of reasons and know it is really hard to stop. “They can help smokers quit using a method which suits them, whether it be vaping, patches or something .” The research also found one in  ex-smokers managed to give cigarettes the heave-ho by taking up vaping instead – saving pound. a year on average.   But  per cent believe quitting by going cold turkey is the best method – despite the NHS saying they’re actually four times more likely to give up for good with support from a stop smoking service. Surprisingly the number one reason those polled want to quit is not health reasons [ per cent] – it’s lack of money [ per cent]. Other motivators include pressure from family or friends [ per cent], becoming a parent or grandparent [ per cent] and the death of a family member or close friend from smoking [ per cent]. Thirty-nine per cent of smokers polled have stuck with the habit because they claim it relaxes them,  per cent carry on because ‘it breaks up the day’ and  per cent continue to puff away because their friends do. Three quarters of everyone polled regret starting to smoke – reasons why include how expensive it is, that it makes your clothes smell and suffering from health conditions. The Yorkshire Cancer Research survey carried out through OnePoll found more than half believe fewer people are smoking because it is not as socially accepted.  And  per cent think the smoking ban has had an impact. Dr Scott added: “There are a whole host of methods for quitting and as the results show, many of those polled think cold turkey is the best way to stop. “However those who use this method might be suffering needlessly - support makes quitting for good so much easier and so much more likely.”

title: twitter thread reveals incredible everyday
story: NewsTwitter thread reveals strangers incredible random acts of kindnessPeople took to Twitter to tell tales of wonderful acts of kindness that allowed them to see loved ones or just made a bad day betterShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  MAR NewsSmall kindnesses like holding up an umbrella for someone can make their day [file image] "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts become a thing on Twitter to ask a random question and see what happens. Most times a small group swap answers but occasionally – as happened when Yoko Ono recently asked for advice to makes lives “heal and shine” it all goes viral. Many replies came with tongues placed firmly in cheeks but the latest version of the social media phenomenon tugs at heartstrings. Writer Nicole Clfe posed the question: “What is the kindest thing a stranger has done or said to you ” Here are the emotional answers... @krausesuzyWhen I was  mos pregnant I slipped on ice, knocked out cold. When I came to, there was a crowd without coats . Their coats were all on top of me, except one under my head.@EmmylouisejaneNot me, but I’ve had this saved to my phone since  as a reminder to be a better stranger: “Thank you to the man who gave me p in the car park at West Middlesex Hospital last Tuesday. Thanks to you I was able to see my father alive for the last time.”@meaghaniMy brother fought PTSD from two tours of duty in Iraq and died by suicide in . My uncle wanted to treat my parents and I to dinner, and when my dad made a reservation they askedit was for a special occasion. Overcome with grief, he shared the details. We went through dinner, ordered up a storm, drank a lot of wine, and asked for the bill. The waiter came back with his manager, said that his brother was killed in action while serving and asked specicallyhe could be our waiter that evening. Our waiter took out the Gold Star pin the government gave him to honor his brother’s death and gave it to my mother, saying he appreciated my brother’s service and our family’s sacrice. Then the manager told us that the restaurant was picking up our nearly  bill.@elizaecampbellI was walking along the road alone in Amman, Jordan in a very LIGHT drizzle. A guy pulls over and tries to give me a ride. Slightly wary, and nervous about speaking Arabic I say no, and then he wordlessly hands me an umbrella, smiles, and drives away. @HoarseWispererMy son almost didn’t survive his first  hours. His first week he was just covered in tubes and sensors and wires. All I could touch were his feet. One night, a nurse named Maureen bent the rules and swaddled him in a tiny blanket and said, “Do you want to hold your son ” I sat with him in my arms for the first time. He’s  now. I will never not cry telling that story.@AnAspidistraLanded in Londonto discover trains on strike. Went to bus station, trying to get to Scotland. Chaos. Inspector closed barrier. A woman on the other side of the barrier heard my Scottish accent and said, ‘That’s my daughter!’ They let me through.@twoscootersWhen I was married to my first husband, I had a year-old baby and it was Christmas, and I was flying from Montgomery, Alabama to Columbus, Ohio. Ex was deployed in the UAE and I was depressed and a mess. The flights got delayed due to snow, then cancelled. We ended up sitting around the gate sharing sob stories. One guy was in the army and headed home for Christmas to see his little girl. Then the announcements: a bunch of people got seats for the next flight, but not me. My tired daughter was crying I was barely not crying. The airline rep called my name and gave me a ticket. Army guy gave up his seat for me. I tried to insist he take it to see his family: “Any military husband would do the same for my we.” I was able to spend Christmas with my family. He didn’t.@TweetChizoneI used to manage an LGBT bookstore. One night, a caller says he thinks he might be gay and is considering self-harm. We were not a crisis centre! But as long as we’re talking, he’s safe, right  So I talk to this guy and I try to be encouraging and I’m maybe sounding a little frantic and I’m definitely ignoring the - customers, and this angel of a woman puts her hand on my shoulder and asks for the phone. “My turn,” she says. And SHE, this -something lesbian talks to this stranger. And a LINE FORMS BEHIND HER. Every customer knows that feeling, and takes a turn talking to that man.@hatergeneAfter my  yr old son was hit by a car, a young woman ran down from her apartment nearby when she heard the screams. She gave him CPR. She held him as he died. She wrote me a letter to let me know he wasn’t alone. Wasn’t scared. #hero@CJPendragonWe once had a man wait outside a restaurant for god knows how long. When we got to our car he told us he noticed our car seats AND that our brakes were visibly bad. He worked for a garage  replaced our brake system free to keep the kids safe because he knew it would be expensive. I’m sure I randomly cried over it for a week. Our dinner was a huge irresponsible treat because things were so hard and both kids were under the age of . He saved us hundreds of dollars, possibly our lives. @ShelbyHintzeI was in middle school and I broke my digital camera. My dad had been travelling a lot and I knew my mom was stressed so I told her I wanted to go to the mall to hang out. I really wanted to seethe Sony store would fix the camera. The guy said there was nothing they could do and I left on the verge of tears. He ran out after me and handed me a new, refurbished camera. I try to buy Sony when I can.@AnneLouiseAveryI was in Cairo, aged , with no cash,  the bank had closed for a holiday. I burst into tears outside  one of the security guards opened the door, then rang his sister who worked in a bureau de change. Her bureau was across the other side of the city, so one of the bank tellers  the guard , finished closing up, then drove me across Cairo. The lovely sister kept her branch open, until we arrived.@EverywhereEricaI’d lost my job, my laptop fried, and my car broke down, all within  days. I was sitting in the car shop, worrying to a friend on the phone abt the cost, then mins later the mechanic handed me my keys  said the lady ahead of me overheard  paid for the repair.@stanthemanchanWhen I went with my sister on vacation to London in , she left her handbag containing her passport ID in a taxi. We were in a panic until finally we called the Canadian consulate and it turns out the cab driver had dropped it off there.

story: NewsWorld Book Day: Parents spend more on outfits than they do on novelsParents can spend up to £ on costumes for their children so they can out-do their classmatesShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  MAR NewsParents spend more money on outfits than novels for World Book Day [file image] "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents spend more on fancy dress outfits for their children on World Book Day than they do on literature each year, a survey reveals. But with two-thirds of primary school pupils demanding a costume, mums and dads admit to feeling stressed by the occasion. Six in  adults think it is now a fancy dress parade rather than a celebration of books.Favourite literary character costumes range from Harry Potter to Gangsta Granny. Online auction site eBay, who commissioned the poll, said: “We want to inspire families to reconnect with World Book Day’s meaning so we’ve curated a list of new and used books.”  Royal Mail has unveiled four decorative postboxes that honour authors of children’s literature for World Book Day. CS Lewis has one in Belfast, Frances Hodgson Burnett in Manchester and Judith Kerr in Barnes, south-west London. Gangsta Granny writer David Walliams, whose yellow one is in central London, hoped children will be inspired to post more letters.
