title: genie wiley haunting story feral
story: NewsGenie Wiley: Haunting story of feral child found mute and hopping like rabbitFor  years, Genie Wiley was imprisoned in the second bedroom of her Calornia home by her dad Clark because he suspected she was mentally disabledShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-BillingsDeputy News Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video haunting-tale-feral-child-genie-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGenie Wiley hopped and held her hands in front of her like a rabbit when she was discovered by social services. She was  but had the mental age of a baby and after thorough examinations, experts said she demonstrated the most severe case of child abuse on record. The teenager was mute and could not chew so instead held food in her mouth until saliva broke it down. Regardless of where she was she constantly spat, snfing and blowing her nose on anything that happened to be nearby. Genie occasionally touched herself intimately without caring who was near and, despite getting upset and angry, she never cried. The -year-old showed understanding of only her own name and two phrases - stop it and no more. She was abnormally pale, grossly malnourished and the lead her father kept her on had caused a thick, bruised callus to form on her backside.   The case of Genie the feral child became known to the world as one of the most horric examples of child abuse and neglect ever uncovered in the United States. From , she had been imprisoned in the second bedroom of her family home by her dad, Clark Wiley, because he suspected she was mentally disabled. After Genies rescue in , Clark was discovered to be a controlling man who hated noise and did not want children.   His first child died after being left in a cold garage and a second from birth complications. A third, a boy named John, survived, followed five years later by the girl who would become known as Genie. According to researchers, Clark did not speak to her and he instructed her we, Irene, and son John to do the same. From -months-old, Genie had been strapped into a handmade straightjacket and tied to a potty chair in a silent room during the day.   At night, she was locked inside a cot with a wire cover and fed almost entirely on liquids. Clark growled and barked at his daughter like a dog andshe made a noise, he beat her with a stick. Irene, stricken by fear and poor eyesight, finally fled the house of horrors in . Plagued by cataracts, she mistakenly blundered into the wrong welfare office seeking a disability pension and a social worker spotted Genie. She seemed unsteady on her feet, her limbs jerked and she held her hands in front of her body like a rabbit. Clark Wiley was charged over their treatment of his daughter but killed himself on the day of his trial. According tohe left behind a note that read: The world will never understand.The girls story was told in newspapers and TV bulletins around the world, and later sparked an Emmy-winning documentary,Secret of the Wild Child. Scientic researchers also flocked around the feral child and Genies status soon changed from welfare case to case study. After a long hospital stay, she was moved through a series of foster homes as experts continued to monitor her growth and behaviour. It is not publicly known where Genie is now. It was reported in  that she was living in a state care facility, approaching her th birthday.

title: flight attendants incredibly sweet gesture
story: NewsFlight attendants incredibly sweet gesture to mum after baby throws up on planeIf you were in need of a little reaffirmation that there is still some good in the world, this might just do the trickShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR NewsA woman shared a sweet story about a flight attendant helping her on a plane"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email With Brexit rapidly approaching and the tragic news of Luke Perrys death hitting us all hard, you might be in need of a lighter read. Well, youve come to the right place, because were taking a look at some incredible random acts of kindness. And its all thanks to a writer named Nicole Clfe, who tweeted on Monday, asking people to share the nicest thing a stranger has ever said or done for them.Nicole went on to discuss the time her baby got sick on a plane and threw up all over her just as they were leaving the gate.   She claims the plane had toto the airport, so her seat could be replaced. Everyone hated me and I was standing, covered in puke, holding my now only diaper-clad baby and trying not to cry while business travelers glared at me, she wrote. And then a flight attendant took my baby and gave me a pair of yoga pants from her carry-on and wrote her address on a napkin so I could mail them back. She added: I firmly believe that she will go to heaven no matter what she may do in the rest of her le.  Thousands liked her post and quickly began sharing their own sweet stories. One person replied: Oh God, I cant even tell this story and not cry. I used to manage an LGBT bookstore, when bookstores were still a thing. One night, a caller says he thinks he might be gay and is considering self-harm. Were not a crisis centre! But as long as were talking, hes safe, right  So I talk to this guy and I answer questions and I try to be encouraging and Im maybe sounding a little frantic and Im definitely ignoring the - customers in the store, and this angel of a woman puts her hand on my shoulder and asks for the phone.   My turn, she says. And SHE, this -something lesbian talks to this stranger on the phone. And a LINE FORMS BEHIND HER. Every customer in that store knows that call, knows that feeling, and every person takes a turn talking to that man. Another person admitted: Had one day to start IVF with no warning due to aggressive cancer diagnosis. Private cost ,, Doc made a call to public hospital, got in same day. Nurses all stayed late to get my treatment underway. Cost: basically free. Got two eggs and . years later had my baby daughter.   And it didnt stop there. Someone  said: I fainted on the subway once and a kind, elderly Chinese woman who spoke no English waited with me, held my hand and fed me grapes while we waited for the EMTs. When they finally came, she patted my hand three times and put my hand on her heart before leaving. A woman named Jenner added: One time I was finishing a reading before class and was sitting on a bench outside. A stranger tapped my shoulder and said Im sorry, but the way the light was shining on you, you looked like an angel. I think about her every day.You can read all of the heartwarming replies to Nicoles post here.Whats the nicest thing a stranger has ever done for you  Let us know in the comments below.

title: north korea reopens nuclear bases
story: NewsNorth Korea reopens its nuclear bases following breakdown of summit with TrumpNorth Korea has started rebuilding its key missile-test facilities which it uses to launch satellites into orbitShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  MAR NewsNorth Korea has started rebuilding its key missile-test facilities which it uses to launch satellites into orbit "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNorth Korea has started rebuilding key nuclear missile test facilities, experts believe. The revelation comes days after the breakdown of a summit meeting between the rogue nation’s dictator Kim Jong-un and President Donald Trump in Hanoi, Vietnam. According to US military analysts and South Korean intelligence officials, North Korea has started rebuilding the plant it uses to launch satellites into orbit and run tests for its intercontinental ballistic missile program. Satellite images appear to show work being carried out, raising questions about the future of US-North Korea negotiations.   Monitoring websites said they had observed activity at the Tongchang-ri facility, which has been dormant since around August of last year. Researchers said rebuilding began between February  and March  – either in the days before, during or immediately after Kim and Trump abruptly ended their second summit without signing a deal. North Korea had partially taken down an engine test site, a rocket launchpad and a rail-mounted building used by engineers to assemble launch vehicles and move them to the launchpad. The CIA has declined to comment on the images.

title: not possible madeleine mccann carried
story: NewsNot possible Madeleine McCann was carried out window by abductor says former superintendentFormer superintendent Peter MacLeod claims in a podcast about Madeleine McCanns disappearance that the window is too small for a normal-sized man carrying a child to get throughShareByDavid WhitefieldTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsIt has been  years since Madeleine was seen "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former superintendent at Nottinghamshire Police has claimed it would not have been possible for an abductor to carry Madeleine McCann out of the window at the apartment where she was sleeping. Three-year-old Madeleine went missing on the evening of May ,  from an apartment at the Ocean Club complex in Praia da Luz, Portugal, where she was sleeping with her twin siblings. A new podcast, Maddie, hosted by Australian journalist Mark Saunokonoko, features contributions from former Nottinghamshire officer Peter MacLeod. Madeleines mother Kate McCanns speculation that an abductor could have carried her out of a window as she and her husband Gerry said they believed someone had jemmied open the shutters to get into the bedroom was discussed on the second episode.  Mr MacLeod, who had visited Praia da Luz and inspected Madeleines ground floor bedroom window at the resort, said it was not possible for a man to carry a three-year-old child out the window, Nottinghamshire Live reports.In the second episode of the podcast, released on Sunday March , Mr MacLeod said: The window is only absolute maximum cm wide, in reality about cm wide, and its already a metre off the ground. I had a [inaudible] at that and my shoulders are wider than that little window. So although you could climb in sideways you certainly cant jump inyou are a normal-sized person. I frankly do not think its possible.   He then expressed other concerns about the window and said it raised a first red flag. He said it was obvious from local television footage that the window shutters were not damaged, smashed, forced or jemmied. And this was in contrast to the stories in the British media that both the window and the shutters were damaged.   Peter MacLeod retired in  and moved from his West Bridgford home to the village of Ronda in south Spain with his partner Claire Casson the following year. He has visited Praia da Luz and written an e-book about the case called What Really Happened to Madeleine McCann  which looks a number of key aspects of the case, including the sightings of a man carrying a child, the photos taken at the time, and whether Madeleine and her siblings were sedated. Madeleine would now be , turning  in May this year. In November , Operation Grange, the Met Police investigation into her disappearance, was given a further pound, from the Home Office, providing funding up to March  this year.   The parents, Kate and Gerry, last updated the official Find Madeleine website on the th anniversary of her disappearance last year. They wrote: Thank you to everyone who continues to support us and wish us, especially Madeleine, well. After eleven years such warmth and persisting solidarity is truly remarkable, and at the same time a real tonic and boost to our spirit.So far three episodes of the podcast have been released. A Netflix documentary about the case is set to be broadcast later this month.* Anyone with information about Madeleine McCann’s disappearance should call the Find Madeleine investigation line on   or email investigation@findmadeleine

title: woman vaginal condition gives birth
story: NewsWoman with vaginal condition gives birth despite having never had sexRevati Bordawekar has never had sex due to a condition that makes her vagina clench when touchedShareCommentsByTfany Lo:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsRevati Bordawekar has never had sex due to a condition that makes her vagina clench when touched "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has given birth after conceiving a baby through IVF although she has never had sex because of a condition which makes her vagina clench when touched. Revati Bordawekar, , from Ahmednagar, India, had sensed something was wrong when the thought of using a tampon made her vaginal muscles clench. At the age of , Revati tried to use a tampon for the first time but failed as her hand began to shake and the vaginal opening seized shut. When Revati married Chinmay at the age of , she told her husband of the condition she thought she might have.  She took advice from medical advisers and friends - drinking wine before sex, practising foreplay and even using numbing cream around the labia. But nothing worked and she eventually turned to doctors for help. Revati was put under general anaesthetic for checks and she was later diagnosed with a condition known as vaginismus - when the muscles around the vaginal opening contract involuntarily. The doctors surgically cut her hymen and dilated her in the hopes that she would overcome the condition. However, it had little effect so the couple tried IVF and got pregnant in May last year.   Revati said: We were desperate to overcome it because we wanted to get pregnant, so I looked at the vaginismus support groups for ways to get pregnant. They suggested using syringes to collect semen then inserting it as far as possible into the vagina. We tried an IUI under general anaesthesia because of vaginismus which failed. So we did our first IVF cycle and our second cycle finally worked. Revati had always intended on a C-section delivery due to her vaginismus, but after meeting with midwives and attending birth classes, Revati knew that shed made it this far, so she wanted to experience the full birthing journey.  During the delivery, Revati had to psyche herself up for pushing and despite her vaginismus, she welcomed daughter Eva in February . My daughter was born on February  after  hours of labour. I was at a . cm dilation when I finally had to ask for an epidural because my contractions were getting too intense and I was in great pain. When my midwe said it was time to start pushing, I asked for five minutes to brace myself. I thought about my struggle with vaginismus since my teens, the years of being told to relax and it will happen. I thought of how bad I felt each time I was deprived of something that came naturally to most, yet this was my only chance to experience the miracle of vaginal birth. And then I was ready to start pushing.   Revati said they have not tried sex yet but she is not confident that it wont be a barrier anymore. Ill always remind myself thatI can push a six-pound baby with a head circumference of  cm out my vagina, I can easily take in a penis with much lesser circumference inside of me, she said. I want to show that vaginismus doesnt stop you from giving birth to your baby. Coming from someone like me with severe primary vaginismus -I could do it, you can too.

title: andrew davies making real progress in bid to help dundee avoid relegation
story: Andrew Davies has told boss Jim McIntyre he’ll be back ahead of schedule to help Dundee escape the drop.The central defender joined the club at the start of January but broke his foot in his first outing in dark blue in a bounce game.The -year-old former Ross County skipper was expected to play a big role in the Dens gaffer’s survival bid but has had to look on from the sidelines.He spent a few weeks recovering down south recently but is back in Dundee and on the training pitch, eager to gain his fitness to be able to finally make his bow for the Dens Park club.Jim said: “Davo is back running.“He’s made real progress over the last couple of weeks.“Sunderland gave us permission to use their anti-gravity machine which has helped bring him on so we’re thankful to Jack Ross for that.“It has helped but he’s over six weeks now, will be seven weeks tomorrow so he’s where we expected him to be.“Hopefully, he can shave a week off it but we’ll pick it up day by day and see how he feels.“Him being him, he’s telling me it’ll be sooner than that because he’s desperate to get out there.“What we don’t want is any recurrence so we’ll be guided on how he is feeling.”Davies has been joined by goalkeeper Jack Hamilton this week after the stopper had a wire removed from his broken finger after surgery at the start of the year.Jim added: “Jack is coming on fine. He got the wire out of his finger last week.“He can start his comeback proper and he’s keeping Andrew Davies company at the moment – they’ve done a lot together on the bikes and they’re doing running on the training ground so it’s great to see them coming back.”Meanwhile, two bodies he’d like back sooner are nearing aand Jim is hoping he’ll have his striking options boosted for Saturday’s home clash with Hearts.Frontmen Andrew Nelson and Craig Curran missed the - defeat to Rangers last midweek but have a chance of athis week.“They are coming on, slow,” Jim said.“They aren’t back on the training ground yet but we’re hoping we’ll have at least one back training by the end of the week.“Craig had an injection in his stomach last week which has settled down nicely but it needs time.“Nelson is his heel which he picked up celebrating his goal at Livingston.“Again that is better but it’s not fully away yet.“What we don’t want to do is bring him back too early and there is a recurrence.“We’ve tried a couple of dferent things but he was tender last week and we had to back off.“It was better over the weekend so we’ll see what he’s like by the end of the week.”At Ibrox, Jim opted for on-loan forward Scott Wright to lead the line in an attempt to catch Steven Gerrard’s Rangers on the hop with pace and will have that option again. However, he’d welcome goalscorer Nelson and “focal point” Curran back.The Dens gaffer said: “Craig has been a focal point for us and brings a lot of people into play in terms of the work he puts in and how he doesn’t let defenders settle.“We went for pace against Rangers by putting Scott Wright up and pace on the sides with Jesse Curran and Andy Dales.“That wasn’t an easy decision because we had Kenny Miller’s experience there as well but we felt we could get down the sides of them when their full-backs went forward but we met them on a night when they were excellent.”

story: Tele readers will be able to enjoy the best sights Norway and Scotland have to offer when the paper sets sail on its very own cruise adventure.The exclusive Tele voyage on the majestic Magellan cruise ship  will depart on a nine-night tour around some of the most breath-taking scenery in the world.With up to , passengers, the glamorous ship will visit awe-inspiring fjords and some of Scotland’s stunning islands.A convenient departure from the Port of Dundee means you can look forward to leaving the hassles of airports behind and get straight into holiday mode.The journey evokes nostalgic memories of the days when The Tele#s parent company ran a famous shipping line in the s.There will be plenty of entertainment on board as well during the special trip # all organised by The Tele#s owners DC Thomson and ship operator Cruise and Maritime Voyages.Fresh delights will await every day as a dedicated team of expert chefs and attentive restaurant staff serve up delicious meals and a luxurious evening dining experience with up to five courses.Magellan, named after the great explorer Ferdinand Magellan, offers an incredible iety of activities within its ftframe, including a show lounge, pubs, coffee shops, casino and shopping galleria.The Tele Magellan voyage departs from Dundee on June  , and arrives back in Greenock  days later # after taking in sights including Flam, Bergen and Portree.While best known these days for its industry-leading publishing work, DC Thomson has a long and proud association with the sea.Following his success in business, William Thomson II looked to the seas and purchased a stake in a sailing ship.His involvement escalated over the years when he purchased more vessels.Eventually, with a fleet of , the Thomson family was responsible for one of the most invaluable shipping firms in the world and provided essential aid to South Africa during the Boer War.Andrew Thomson, chairman of DC Thomson, said: “It’s wonderful to see DC Thomson realigning with its heritage by ing to the seas.“When William Thomson established the Thomson Shipping Line in the th century I’m sure he didn’t contemplate that over  years later DC Thomson would be transporting passengers by ship around the Scottish Isles and Norway.“This kind of ersication of the business is a great fit for DC Thomson.”Craig Houston, head of enterprise for DC Thomson Media, said: “Working with Cruise  Maritime Voyages to bring this highly desirable sailing route to DC Thomson Travel customers has been a pleasure.“We’re excited to be offering such a special route with a trusted partner and we can’t wait to hear what our passengers say about this amazing trip.”

title: dundee skipper martin woods says side need to keep their heads to avoid relegation
story: Martin Woods says Dundee need to keep their heads in the “crazy” Premiership run-in as they attempt to battle their way to safety.The Dark Blues dropped back into the relegation play-off place after a - thumping dished out by Rangers last Wednesday on the back of a - home defeat to Hibs.However, it was a surprise result at Pittodrie that saw Woods  Co. drop back down the league as Hamilton Accies defeated Aberdeen -, with Saturday also seeing St Mirren close the gap below to one point by defeating Livingston -.Woods, has captained the side recently in Josh Meekings# continued absence, said: “Hamilton was a real shock, I didn’t see that coming at all.“Coming in to hear that after the game was a blow but there will be lots of ups and downs between now and the end of the season, we just need to take care of our own business and, hopefully, that will be enough to steer us clear.“I don’t think anybody would have seen after their game against Rangers, Hamilton going up to Aberdeen and winning - but it’s a crazy league.“Weeks ago, nobody would have seen us going to Tynecastle and getting a result so there will be ups and downs and we have to stick together.“We’ve looked through the Rangers game and seen what we can do better defensively as a team and take that on to the next bunch of games to get some points on the board.”With no match over the weekend due to the Scottish Cup taking priority, it’s been a welcome break for the Dark Blues after a couple punishing results.Woods hopes the breather will allow them to up their game when Hearts come calling on Saturday.“I think it’s been a tough run of games so it’s been good to sit back, reflect and get ready to go again,” he added.“We’ll work on a few things in the training ground and take it into the next bunch of games which are going to be vital.“We have a couple of tough ones coming up with Hearts at home, which we hope to get something out of, and then Celtic at home will be a day we have to be disciplined and get off to a lot better start than we did at Rangers.”If they keep their discipline and manage to up their level from the first half at Ibrox, Woods is confident their luck will turn to help them make it two wins in a row against Hearts, after their - victory at Tynecastle in January.He added: “Against Livingston, they went down to  men, we got a goal in the last seven minutes, we could’ve had a penalty against us so we’ll get days where things go for you.“That’s probably two in a row where nothing’s gone for us at all against Hibs and Rangers.“There will be loads of twists and turns before now and the end of the season, we just need to focus on our performance levels and try to keep that high.“We dropped in the first half against Rangers which wasn’t great but that was a mixture of both them being really good and us not doing as well as we could.“The first goal from a set-piece, we weren’t tight enough and got punished.“From there you could see them get a lt and that’s an important thing to do at Ibrox, to start well.“It was very frustrating but we’ll not be judged by games like away at Ibrox, there will be a lot of big games to come before now and the end of the season.”Woods is also keen to repay the club’s support that has been starved of home success this season with the number of home wins the worst in the ision.“The fans have stuck with us and they were brilliant against Hibs.“I think they can see the performance level has been better in recent weeks.”

title: former dundee united defender harry souttar called into australian squad
story: Former Dundee United defender Harry Souttar has been called into the Australia U  squad.The -year-old, who is on loan at Fleetwood Town from current employers Stoke City, has accepted a call-up for Australia’s Olympic qualication squad for their training camp in Malaysia and qualiers in Cambodia.Souttar has already represented Scotland at U  and U  level and, along with brother John, is poised to be the first Scottish siblings to play for dferent countries.John made his international debut last year after Hearts boss Craig Levein warned Scotland risked losing him to Australia because he was eligible to play for the Socceroos.Harry had previously insisted it was his dream to play for Scotland.He#s eligible to play for Australia through his mother, who was born in Australia.He stressed two years ago during Scotland U ’s Elite Round qualiers in Czech Republic he was desperate to play for his country.He said: “My ambition has always been to play for Scotland. Who knows, maybe one day I will partner John at the centre of defence for Scotland.“My aim is to try to get myself established in English football and then see what happens.”But Socceroos boss Graham Arnold, who is also in charge of the U  side, insists he’s delighted to have persuaded the former Tangerines and Ross County stopper to follow in the footsteps of Hibs winger Martin Boyle and pledge their future for Australia.The Aussies were alerted to Souttar’s availability by his Stoke City team-mate Adam Federici.Arnold said: “When you look at Harry and his size, he is a beast. title: BrewDog eyes up Inverness site for bar
story: A CITY bakery looks set to make way for a hip new bar in Inverness city centre.The Ashers bakery chain has confirmed this week that it is "at an advanced stage of negotiations" over vacating its premises in Church Street to make way for Aberdeenshire-based BrewDog.It was revealed last month that the pub chain, which has grown rapidly in the past few years and now employs more than  staff in dozens of bars across the UK, was keen to come to the Highland capital.While there has been no official confirmation from BrewDog itself Ali Asher, joint managing director of the Ashers chain, confirmed talks are progressing."Its clearly a very good site for that type of operation now," he said, adding that Ashers itself will not be leaving the city centre but simply moving."We have also identied a location round the corner on Union Street which we plan to relocate to at the same time," he said."We hope the necessary consents and assistance from the authorities and our local tradesmen will facilitate this being a smooth transition."Mr Asher also revealed plans for a refurbishment of his chains cafe at the Farraline Park bus station."We look forward to welcoming many loyal and new customers to both these shops and wish BrewDog all the best," he added.BrewDog was launched in Fraserburgh in  by friends Martin Dickie and James Watt, both then , with a mission to increase interest in craft beer.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to transfer ownership of the venue in Ardross Street from Highland Council to a community-run organisation in a bid to enable greater public access and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildingsBut its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It is a repeat of a successful two-week trial opening last summer when hundreds took up the chance to enjoy the space for ious uses including family outings, outdoor office meetings and picnic lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us knowthey want to form a programme of events and we can seeit is something we can put on, he said.ldquoIf people are out and about in the park there might be a shinty game going on, for example, or a pipe band.Another possibility might be a Teddy bearsrsquo picnic.The group is also in talks with the Care and Learning Allianceabout future possibilities to use the location for childcare provision .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving refreshments.Jaci Douglas, Calarsquos chief executive, said during discussions with the community over a year ago, flexible and accessible childcare was identied as one of the needs in the area along with a possible use for the park space.ldquoWe have been working closely with the Northern Meeting Park Group on how best to meet that aspiration, she said.ldquoAs an early years charity, Cala is well placed to work with partners to provide a quality early learning and childcare service and we are really excited about the opportunity to do that in close collaboration with the community group, Highland Council and Highland Le Highland as well as with local parents although itrsquos still at the early planning stages. ldquoThursday  Mar  : AM

title: Candlelight tribute for Highland musician
story: A SOPRANO singer has paid tribute to her ldquospecial friend who inspired her to perform a candlelit concert to raise pound for a cancer care charity.Liz McLardy laid on an evening of music and song for Maggiersquos Highlands to show her admiration to staff who lted the spirits of her close friend Helen Sproston in the final days of her le.Mrs Sproston, a -year-old artist and musician who played alto saxophone in the Bonny Vista Social Club, and the Highland Swing band, would have been parted from her beloved Tibetan terrier called Mac had Maggiersquos not allowed friends to bring the dog in for visits while she was being treated at neighbouring Raigmore Hospital.The concert, called Baroque by Candlelight, in which Ms McLardy performed with pianist Tonya Clement and James Ross on clarinet, was held at St Johnrsquos Church in Inverness on February .Poignantly, Mrs Sproston passed away on the same day.Ms McLardy said: ldquoHelen was special. She was just so full of le. She did all sorts of outrageous things like climbing Mont Blanc and she travelled a lot.ldquoShe was a good artist and musician and she loved her little dog. She was unique. Yoursquod never have believed she was in her seventies.Mrs Sprostonrsquos ex-sister-in-law Kay Hall, with whom she attended Altrincham Grammar School in Cheshire, and had held a close bond as the pair married twin brothers, said Mrs Sproston has a son, Stuart, who lives in Barcelona. Her late husband Ron died several years ago.Paying her own tribute, she said: ldquoHelen was a free spirit and a very determined woman. Some people would say she was stubborn and that helped with the diagnosis. She was determined to make best use of the time that she had left.Bonny Vista Social Club guitarist Pete Gavin said he enjoyed Helenrsquos ldquohard-wit and her stoic approach to living and dying.He said: ldquoA couple of us in the band are aware of our own mortality for ious reasons and Helen was a good example for us because her attitude was very much like lsquoitrsquos time for the last song and Irsquom okay with thatrsquo.Fellow band members made a music recording for her, which she wanted to be played at her funeral.She also recorded a few final words which were edited into the track, thanking friends for all their love and good wishes and paying special thanks to the exceptional buddy who ldquosneaked in the GTs during visits.Then the music fades out with her laughter, Helenrsquos parting gt.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Date set for Highland air traffic controllers strike
story: Air traffic controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airport Limitedare set to strike on April , affecting operations at Inverness Airport as well as in Dundee, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Members of the Prospect union will also take action short of a strike between April and August , in a continuing disagreement over their pay offer for -.This will include instruction to work to rosters an overtime ban and withdrawal of goodwill though Prospect says it will seek to agree a protocol with Hial to ensure cover for emergency incidents.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoProspect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.ldquoI urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Eastgate road closed as hostel demolition work begins
story: Motorists are being advised that Eastgate inInverness will be closed at its junction with Crown Road to its junction with Inglis Street from today until Friday.The closure is to allow demolition work to be carried out at the former Eastgate Hostel building which starts this week, more than five years after the fire that left it gutted.Pedestrian access remains open and access for emergency services and delivery vehicles will be at the discretion of the works contractor.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness College UHI lecturers on strike again
story: COLLEGE lecturers are on strike today after pay talks failed to produce any agreement.Members of the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Association in Inverness have joined colleagues across Scotland in striking, with another strike set for March .It follows two one-day strikes earlier this year in pursuit of a cost of living pay increase.Picket lines were seen outside Inverness College UHI at Inverness Campus.Talks aimed at averting the strikes broke down without a resolution, leaving representatives for colleges exasperated, according to the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Association.John Gribben, the associationrsquos director of employment services, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made it clear that there is no more money for lecturersrsquo pay and colleges have to find the pay deal on offer by making cuts.ldquoIf there were any more money available, our priorities would be for additional investment in enhancing studentsrsquo experiences and on further improving college campuses.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Thursday  Mar  : AM

title: ex don quinn thinks club would love to keep consistent considine
story: Former Don Paul Quinn believes keeping long-serving Andy Considine would be a great piece of business for Aberdeen.Quinn had a six-month spell at Pittodrie during the - season and saw at close quarters what Considine brings to the Reds.The -year-old is in his th season with the Dons, but his contract is up in the summer.Discussions have taken place about a new deal, but no extension has been signed yet. Having played with and against Considine, Quinn thinks keeping him would be good business for Aberdeen.The former Motherwell, Cardf and Ross County centre-back said: “Aberdeen as a club will always have to sign players from England or from where in Scotland.“But it is still very important to have people from the area who have come through the ranks, know what it’s about and know the pressure of playing for the club.“The Andy Considines and Graeme Shinnies are those players. Andy has been a great servant to Aberdeen, I played with Andy for a period in my career and I’ve known him for a long time.“We were in Scotland age group squads and I’ve played against and with him over a near -year period.“I have seen how consistent he is and along with that he is a top fella and a great guy in the dressing room.”Club captain Graeme Shinnie, pictured below, is also out of contract at the end of the season.The Dons skipper is currently deliberating his future with plenty of interest in him from English Championship clubs.Quinn, who has started his own business during a break from the game after leaving Dundee United last summer. believes it may be tougher for Aberdeen to keep Shinnie.The -year-old added: “Graeme is similar to Andy in knowing what the club is about but it might be dficult for Aberdeen to keep hold of him. He is a player that I think just keep getting better and contributing more for Aberdeen.“He has got a decision to make but it might be tricky for Aberdeen to keep him because he could play at a higher level.“In Scotland the only higher level in the last few years has been Celtic. Whether Graeme would end up there I don’t know.“But it may be down south where I think there will be big clubs in the English Championship interested in Graeme. I know Aberdeen fans won’t like me saying that, but when you have his ability there will be interest.”On Saturday Aberdeen travel to Parkhead looking to set a club record of eight straight away wins, then on Tuesday they face Rangers at Ibrox in the Scottish Cup quarter-final replay.Under manager Derek McInnes the Dons have shown they are more than capable of beating the Glasgow giants on their own patch.Quinn believes the Reds competing with Celtic and Rangers for honours and beating them away from home is down to the job done by McInnes.He said: “His budgets aren’t as strong as Celtic or Rangers, but he keeps doing it.“He loses good players, but he always manages to bring in good players.“Derek is a top manager working at a top club and with the job he has done I am slightly surprised that he is still there.“But he has built something at Aberdeen and will feel he still has unfinished business and more to achieve at Aberdeen.”Meanwhile, the Dons are set to receive fewer than , tickets for next week’s Scottish Cup replay with Rangers at Ibrox.Competition regulations state the Red Army would be entitled to up to % of the Glasgow ground’s capacity, which would be closer to , briefs.However, it is understood Aberdeen will receive the same amount –  tickets – as they did for the - win over Rangers at Ibrox in December.It is understood the Dons have gauged the level of interest in Tuesday night’s clash among supporters and , is the top end of what they would expect to sell.

title: all aboard documentary on ferry from aberdeen to lerwick to screen this week
story: A documentary focusing on le aboard a ferry from Aberdeen to Lerwick will screen later this week.The STV programme All Aboard will air on Friday and follows NorthLink Ferries’ MV Hrossey along its journey.The -minute show will give an insight into how the ferry runs, and will feature the crew members who spend two weeks on and off at sea. vw, px"  It is part of the This Is Scotland initiative – run by the Scottish Documentary Institutealongside Screen Scotland – as a way for Scottish film-makers to work with SDI and secure a peak-time broadcast on STV.The journey itself normally takes  hours and  minutes, with up to seven crossings a week.The documentary will focus on the captain and second officer, alongside members of the bar staff, detailing their roles and stories.“It will also feature a iety of passengers who take the journey for dferent reasons – from those who are retired to an owner of an art shop who moved from America.Stuart Garrett, Serco’s managing director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “We are extremely excited to be starring in All Aboard.“This is a great opportunity for viewers to see the hard work that goes into maintaining an award-winning service, the range of roles our crew manage and of course hear some really interesting stories from our passengers.”The show was mostly filmed last year and was put together during  trips on the boat.More than  interviews took place in the duration of filming.The ship itself has  en suite cabins as well as restaurants, bars and retail shops on board.The documentary was produced by Duncan Cowles, a -year-old from Currie, Edinburgh, who graduated from Edinburgh College of Art.The graduate’s previous short film works have been showcased at festivals and received awards in Scotland as well as internationally. vw, px"  Duncan said: “It’s totally dferent from what I have done before.“It was nice to do something that’s sole objective was to entertain people, just making them smile.“It was challenging at times filming while on a boat but it was also fun.”He went on to say why he thought the journey would make a good documentary, adding: “I had taken the boat a few times before filming and realised it had a microcosm of its own.“You get all extremes of le on this boat. The film shines a light on le on board and on this lesser-known part of Scotland.“I thought it was nice to show something that has not had a lot done on it. It’s a proper journey overnight and that gives it a romantic feel.”Duncan added: “I am extremely grateful to Serco NorthLink Ferries for allowing me this great opportunity to film on board MV Hrossey and hear about the amazing journeys between mainland Scotland and the Northern Isles.“It was fascinating to hear the many stories of passengers and crew and I’m sure that viewers on Friday evening will be just as captivated by this service which truly is a leline for Orkney and Shetland.”All Aboard will air at pm on Friday on STV.

title: inspectors praise staff at aberdeen nursery05
story: Snack time at an Aberdeen nursery is relaxed and sociable, inspectors said.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited Summers Nursery on Victoria Street, Aberdeen, on January  and have now published their report.The nursery can look after up to  children at any one time and inspectors rated it “very good” for care, support and environment – the second best of six possible ratings.“Children’s health and wellbeing was promoted during snack and meal times,” the report said.It added: “We observed these times to be relaxed, sociable experiences, with the pace dictated by each child’s inidual needs.“Staff joined in with children’s conversations, supporting the development of children’s social skills and language development.“They praised and encouraged the children, which helped them to feel safe, protected and included.”

title: minke whale noises recorded off north east coast for first time
story: The results of a study which saw minke whale noises recorded off the north-east coast for the first time have been revealed.Advancements in technology enabled researchers to record sounds, known as pulse trains, in the water around Fraserburgh, Cruden Bay and Stonehaven for the first time using long-term underwater recorders.Previously recorders were towed behind boats, which led to the noises being drowned out by other sounds. vw, px"  The recording took place from May  to January , with the results, which were published yesterday, showing that the whales’ sounds had been successfully recorded in the area for the first time.Dr Denise Risch, an ecologist at the Scottish Association for Marine Science , developed the software with colleagues from Cornell University in New York.She said: “People haven’t really looked before. I’ve been putting acoustic recorders into the water.“It’s become a lot easier over the past couple of years. The devices are becoming much easier to store and are coming down in price.“The sounds the whales are producing are of a very low frequency.“Humans can hear them, but it’s at the low end of the scale, andyou’re towing a recorder behind you on a boat it gets drowned out by something called flow noise.“It’s much easier when you put a long-term recorder in the water and then go back a few months later and recover it.”The study, which aimed to establish where the sounds could be heard around the north and east coasts of Scotland, found they were mostly detected during June and July – months most commonly associated with the whales’ presence in the area.Dr Risch is hopeful further studies will reveal more about the whales, which are regularly seen around the north of Scotland, including how they are affected by noises created by shipping traffic.She said: “The most interesting thing we found is that they are in fact detectable. I wasn’t surprised by that but it was still a nice confirmation.“We think it may be mainly the males making the noises but that’s still to be confirmed.“We are going to be doing studies on the west coast and we want to compare what we find there with what we found in the east.”

title: plans to transform former north east offshore office building into gym
story: Plans to convert a former offshore office building into a gym have been lodged with a local authority.The proposals would see the Safelt Offshore Ltd premises on Burghmuir Place, Inverurie, converted into a fitness facility.An application has been made for the site by AFH Strategic Contracts on behalf of Milngavie-based Energie Scotland.If accepted, it is likely to provide jobs for around six to eight staff, as well as five freelance class instructors and up to eight self-employed personal trainers.Memberships would be offered on a no-contract basis and would cost around £. per month for use of the gym and all classes.A statement submitted by the firm alongside the application said: “Our chosen site has a catchment population of over ,, in easy access via car or local transport, while its close proximity to the A also means we can attract members from surrounding areas and those commuting into the city centre.“Currently % of the UK population uses a fitness facility and it is generally accepted this will surpass the % figure seen in the USA.”Included in the supporting documentation, the firm has secured support from Dr Danny Ruta, former director of public health Dr David Boddie, a consultant in Aberdeen, and Nick Ruta, most recently operations manager for Sport Aberdeen.The statement added: “The three franchisees, Dr Danny Ruta, Dr David Boddie and Nick Ruta, are deeply committed to health and fitness and are excited at the opportunity to bring their combined skills and experience to the local community.“We will be providing local residents with the opportunity to get fit and healthy at an affordable price and supporting them throughout their journey.”If plans are accepted, it will include a main gym area and free weights area.There will also be male, female and disabled changing rooms, alongside a studio and yoga room.Existing office space will be maintained and there will be a rental space available.

title: scottish government rejects calls for helicopter inquiry
story: The Scottish Government has rejected calls for a public inquiry into North Sea helicopter safety.A total of  offshore workers have died in helicopter incidents in the last decade, all involving the Super Puma model, which is no longer in operation in the UK sector.The Unite and RMT unions, joined by north-east Labour MSP Lewis Macdonald, have been seeking Holyrood support for a UK inquiry into whether “commercial pressures” were jeopardising safety.The group argued there has been a “serious decline” in workforce confidence in offshore transport.Aviation safety is under control of the UK Government so it is Westminster that the group ultimately has to convince.Energy Minister Paul Wheelhouse and transport secretary Michael Matheson have met with the Oil and Gas Authorityand Civil Aviation Authorityrespectively to discuss the issue.In a letter to Lewis Macdonald, Mr Wheelhouse said there is ongoing work being carried out by the industry so a further review or inquiry “would not be helpful”.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. title: islay adds character to new whisky film
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowA new film will tell the tale of Scotland#s national drink # the legendary water of le.Scotch: The Golden Dram, a revealing feature documentary on how whisky became the spirit of choice around the globe, is set for UK release on March .The film, by Parkland Entertainment and Munro Films, will have its European premiere at the Glasgow Film Festival on March .Shot on location among the stunning Scottish countryside, Scotch: The Golden Dram tells the story of uisge-beatha, Gaelic for #water of le#, which is enjoyed in more than  countries, generating more than  billion in exports each year.The film charts the Cinderella tale of legendary master distiller Jim McEwan, a veteran with more than  years standing in the industry, who takes on the dilapidated Bruichladdich distillery on his home island of Islay and turns it into an award-winning blend.Some of the other ardent enthusiasts featured include Richard Paterson, a master blender whose nose was insured for . million, as well as biochemist whisky-maker Dr Bill Lumsden, and master distiller Ian MacMillan.The film marks director-producer Andrew Peat’s feature- documentary debut, a passion project for the American filmmaker who studied at St Andrew’s University.Andrew Peat said: #The heart of our film is the characters, the men and women who produce Scotch whisky, from the barley farmers to the bottle makers. And you can literally see the passion and joy and pride they have in their work and this world-renowned product.#They share their amazing stories, and some very humorous anecdotes. It#s a very educational film , but at the same time it#s a film of the heart.#You will laugh and possibly cry by the time the credits roll.#David Adams McGilp, VisitScotland regional director, said: #Boasting an incredible number of distilleries, Islay is a Mecca for whisky-lovers across the world. It’s great to see the island feature so heavily in the documentary Scotland: The Golden Dram with four distilleries included.#As well as its whisky offering, Islay provides stunning scenery, a wide iety of wildle and a warm Scottish welcome. I hope this film will encourage visitors to travel here to enjoy the water of le, and the island’s remarkable tourism offering.#View a trailer for Scotch: The Golden Dram.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. title: ayr bids fond farewell military
story: NewsAyr bids fond farewell as military funeral held for soldier Jock McKelvieAyr High Street came to a standstill as Staff Sergeant Jock was taken on his final journey.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsJocks coffin is carried from the Aud Kirk "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr came to a reverential standstill for the military funeral of Staff Sergeant John ‘Jock’ McKelvie, writes Edwin Lawrence. Shoppers stopped in their tracks and shopkeepers stood on their doorsteps to honour an Ayrshire soldier. Police sealed off the High Street to cars as the cortege arrived at the Kirk Port entrance to the Auld Kirk. The silence was broken only by the lament of a lone piper as Jock’s family filed their way into church. Jock’s coffin was carried into a packed service by men of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. His coffin was draped in a union flag and on top were his cap, belt, his campaign medals and a wreath. A dozen colleagues in the firing party formed a guard of honour after the coffin had passed under the  lych gate. Jock, , lived in Dundonald with second we Gigliola, better known as Julie. And he ran a log and firewood business, as well as being a yeomanry reservist. He was laid to rest with full military honours at Drongan where he spent his boyhood and where parents Dan and Rita live. The father-of-two died six days after his armoured car overturned at the Catterick Garrison in Yorkshire on January . Among the mourners in the Auld Kirk was Colonel John Dalrymple Hamilton, who was representing Prince Charles. Provost Helen Moonie of South Ayrshire Council also attended the service. And there was military top brass from both regiments in which Jock served –the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards and the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. Other regiments represented included the Royal Engineers, the Royal Artillery, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers and the Le Guards. Members of the Army Cadet Force were also present to pay their respects. Jock was  years in the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards, rising to be a Challenger tank commander. He survived tours of duty in Iraq, Kuwait and Kosovo, only to die in a training exercise. Auld Kirk minister Rev David Gemmell described how John McKelvie ‘grabbed le by the throat’ from his earliest days. He wasn’t much of a scholar at Drongan Primary and Auchinleck Academy, but he knew every creature that ran, crawled, swam or flew in the countryside. And a love of the great outdoors was a huge part of his le – whether it was fishing, playing rugby, ski-ing or mountain biking.  He and we Julie were fond of dogs, and Julie taught her big action man how to ride a horse, said the minister. Major Richard Boyle of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards read the lesson - ‘To every thing there is a season’ from Ecclesiastes. There were hilarious army anecdotes from best buddy JR Ewing, telling how they had shot at each other - with paintballs. J R also mentioned how when Jock was rebuked by a French officer in Kosovo, the big man pointed to his Royal Scots Dragoon Guards cap badge – a French eagle with the word Waterloo underneath. J R, his voice breaking, concluded by saying: “He was the best soldier I ever served with and my best friend.” Former RSDG officer Will Galbraith highlighted Jock’s pride in his regiment, his family and his friends. He said: “He had a strong sense of honour, of right and wrong, and would always stand up for the underdog.” Will said: “He was a big man, with a big voice and a big heart – a big character. But when you really got to know him, he was a big softie – although you wouldn’t tell him that. You had to be aware of those big hands.” Army chaplain Rev Duncan Macpherson said there were bound to be feelings of frustration, anger and regret at the way John McKelvie died. He hoped these would be resolved, adding: “He was someone who was thoroughly tested, who rose to the challenge and who was a thoroughly professional soldier. He was passionate about vehicles and made sure his was ready for any task.” Lt Colonel Toby Gaddum, commanding officer of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, led the congregation in the regimental prayer. Rev David Gemmell brought the church service to an end by poignantly reciting “We Let You Go’. The poem ends: “We love you, we miss you, we want you to be happy. Go safely, go dancing, go running home.” A collection at the end of the service raised vital cash for the Ayrshire Yeomanry Families Fund. Jock was laid to rest at Drongan Cemetery, where a guard of honour fired three volleys from their rles.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrince CharlesRoyal Scots Dragoon GuardsSouth Ayrshire CouncilMiddle EastArmed forcesRoyal FamilyLove and romanceDundonaldAyr NewsAyr

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.
